SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1854, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name ........................................... William George Vicars
2. Your address ............................................. Fort Des Appelle
3. Date ......................................................... Aug 153
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) Lindsay, Victoria County, Ont.
5. What was your father's name and occupation? John Vicars - Anglican Minister
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) June - 1882
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. Connington, Ont. 1876
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc). 19 yrs.
9. What were your reasons for coming West? To procure land.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?). From a brother who had been West, on a survey party in 1881.
Vicars, William George
Fort Qu'Appelle

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: William George Vicars
2. Your address: Fort Qu'Appelle
3. Date: May 5th
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
   Windsor, Victoria County, Ont.
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   John Vicars - Anglican Minister
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   January - 1880
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   Cannington, Ont. 1876
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you are under 18 years of age.)
   17
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   To procure land!
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government literature?)
    From a brother who had been there
    Seen what was a survey party in 1881
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They agreed that it offered wonderful opportunities.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

With a survey party.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Train to Flat Creek (Oak Lake) and ox-cart to Fort Da'Appelle.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.).

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Fort Da'Appelle

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Fort Da'Appelle

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Da'Appelle.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Left school & came west. Homesteader, farming, lumber & book keeper at Dunfield, Black, Indian Head, grain buyer, merchant.
21. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

This appeal that I offered myself.

22. What was your party (family, friends or other group)?

With a survey party.

23. What means of transportation did you use?

Train & Flat Creek (Butte)

24. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

25. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

First In 'Appelle'

26. Where did you settle or take up land?

First In 'Appelle'

27. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

In 'Appelle'

28. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Left work in Alberta & came west. From there, homesteaded at

Glenfield, Swan River, then moved to

Keggs, Truckee.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Every week.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Anne Hilligas, Cannington, Jan 3/1900.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

Jack Vickers, surveyor for Donn Govt. 1881, eventually settled in Kamloops B.C.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

Drove transport in Rail Rebellion from Fort Qu'Appelle to Clark's Crossing. After rebellion freighters supplies from Qu'Appelle to Prince Albert by horse teams and wagons.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? by what means of travel?

Not much. If distance was less than 10 miles, would walk or "dog trot" on foot; otherwise horseback or horse drawn vehicle.
18. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, how many?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell us when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

24. Did you travel about much in the early days? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often?

Forty-three years residence in Newell
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   1906. - Cadillac.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   La'Appelle.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.).
   Yes.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   Once a week.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   1890.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   1900, from Eaton's in Winnipeg.
   Household furnishings, clothes.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   1909. Bell Telephone Co.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   Yes.

What kind of articles did you buy in this way? What was the proportion of your total purchases made by mail order compared to those purchased locally?

1900, from Eaton's & Montgomery's.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

Yes.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

No.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

Very few.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Reeve of Municipality of South In 'Appellee.
Councillor of town of In 'Appellee.
Mayor of In 'Appellee, 1910.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

Wm. Caswell, first automobile.
S. H. Caswell, "general merchant."
Dean Sargent - first Anglican parish.
Dr. W. Henderson, first Mayor of In 'Appellee, 1905.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

In 'Appellee was called Troy, before the C.P.R. went through. The C.P.R. changed the name to In 'Appellee, which is the name of the river & valley running 18 miles north of the railway. Walsh St. in In 'Appellee named after Major Walsh of the C.W.R.R. station at Fort In 'Appellee in 1885.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption; (4) any changes in names since then; (5) date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

The name of the railway was called "Gifford" which is the name of the railway. The railway was named after Major Webb in 1885.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

Coming of the railway, better roads, telegraph & telephone, radio, better school, hospital, and boards of trade.
